description.narrative: Integrating Water, Land and Ecosystems Management in Caribbean Small Island Developing States (IWECO).

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: • Expanded number of small-scale community-based initiatives that bring socio-economic and livelihoods benefits from land, water and ecosystems management • Increased participation of community beneficiaries gaining economic benefits from integrated natural resource management disaggregated by gender and socio-economic status (clear evidence of gender-equity in access to benefits) • Increased average annual income to community beneficiaries • Improved water and sanitation security at local community level • Enhanced stakeholder networking and knowledge sharing towards implementation of solutions across the Caribbean and other SIDS regions • Expanded, strengthened community of practices with shared experiences in successfully implementing solutions

comment.narrative: • Community-based investments in natural resources management remains relatively low -keyed and few in number in consideration of the potential that exists; • limited capacity within community groups to tap into resources • Limited understanding of how investments in land, water and ecosystems resources management contributes to improved economies and sustainable livelihoods • Relatively low engagement of community groups and CSOs in active natural resources management • relative isolation of practitioners with limited opportunities for interactive experience-based learning • limited dissemination and access to resources to practitioners in appropriate formats • many web-based platforms but translation of knowledge to implementation is not well understood; • translation of expert and traditional knowledge to application at community level is limited

• On average at least 40% change in revenue for most directly engaged stakeholders in eco-tourism o Dominican Republic o Jamaica o St Vincent & the Grenadines • IWECO Project website operational • range of printed and electronic media products (including travelling exhibition display for project) • support to at least 1 special promotional blitz in each country (supported by the private sector in association with commemorative days) • support to in-country seminars, lecture series

Progress of SGP Component
The implementation of SGP component has been going well and as planned in most of the eight recipient countries, although they vary in their progress towards the implementation due to different contexts. In all countries, community projects have been developed and implemented with awareness raising, trainings or outreach activities. Meetings and workshops have been organized at the national level to enhance local capacity and awareness. Barbados, despite not receiving funds for national activities has supported projects in alignment with the IWEco priorities. There is a total of 24 community demonstration sites in support of IWEco implementation. 20 projects with a total of $644,423 of IWEco fund are being implemented, with the parallel funds from the SGP core budget supporting 4 projects to date totalling $296,065. The total co-financing is estimated at $665,642.
In Antigua and Barbuda, activities have focused on waste management. The country has the second highest waste output in the world according to the World Economic Forum Report for 2015; 4.4 kg per capita per day of waste is generated on the islands. This is seven times the world average. From a Ridge-to-Reef perspective this creates considerable negative externalities for the environment, wetland areas, water resources and local ecosystems. For this reason, all the SGP-IWEco projects in Antigua and Barbuda focus on the reduction and recycling of waste, and to avoid waste ending up in landfills and local waterways. Three projects have been supported in Antigua and Barbuda. One project works with school children to expand the use of coconut waste. Local research has shown the multiple uses and possibilities of the coconut. This has prompted the need for all parts of the plant to be utilized for drinks, oils, food, for health and nutrition, in agricultural processes and beauty products. Another project seeks to involve youth to research native algae that have adapted to local conditions and will be tested to see how best they can thrive to produce oils for biofuels. The third project seeks to identify multiple uses for waste and to stop them from reaching the landfill, thereby halting the degradation of the ecosystems and the benefits they provide.
In Cuba, two projects with a total budget of $100,000, focusing on coastal natural resource management and waste management respectively, are under implementation, having generated an additional financing of $137,000. Under one project, the scientific institution that is partner to the project has discovered that a species of marine plant, the Syringodium filiforme (that grows associated with the Thalassia testudinum), possesses antiviral and potentially cytostatic biological activity for aiding lung cancer. The project actions will allow a management of the species in addition to its future use in the biopharmaceutical industry. In another project, 60 farmers that have the greatest impact on the pollution of the San Juan River Basin were selected as participants and a training package was developed for them. Start of the diagnosis of the 60 farms to establish their land management plans that will allow declaring these farms as “Sustainable Land Management”.
In the Dominica Republic, three projects have been developed and implemented. 1) Protection of biodiversity, generation of family income and promotion of sustainable livelihoods through the development of beekeeping in 10 communities of the Higuamo River, San Pedro de Macorís province. 2) Reduction of pollution levels in the Lower Basin of the Higuamo River, raising environmental awareness, and positively impact the quality of life of the population and the environment. 3) Improvement of the quality of life of the people and biodiversity conservation, particularly of the forest cover, through the sustainable production of honey in Gonzalo, Los Limones and Mango Fresco, upper basin of the Higuamo river.
In Jamaica, two community projects are under implementation, with a total budget of $87,500 of IWEco financing and a co-financing of $101,500, focusing on biodiversity restoration of Portland Ridge and water quality assessment in Discovery Bay: 1) Portland Ridge in the Portland Bight protected area, is one of the most important areas in the Caribbean for range restricted endemic biodiversity. The protected area supports 12 IUCN red-listed species including 3 reptiles, 1 bat, 1 frog and 5 plants among many other rare species that depend on the dry forest for their habitat. 2) Evaluating coastal water quality at Discovery Bay to improve capacity for environmental management. Of the 30 sites for water quality testing – 14 sites already tested. 162 Ha land-based point sources have been identified and test samples conducted. Awareness meetings held with key stakeholders (private sector, community members, government agencies). Community members trained in scientific field data collection techniques.
In St. Kitts and Nevis, a capacity development workshop was held with 30 participants trained on project development and implementation under IWEco. Two project concepts have been approved. One strategic project on combating land degradation in the Historic New River and Coconut Walk Coastline is under implementation funded by SGP with a total of SGP core funding of $150,000 to support the implementation of IWEco. A documentary was produced.
In Saint Lucia, three projects with a total of $76,816 IWEco funds are being implemented. 1) “Connecting cooperatives to the SDGs and commencing the formative stages of building climate change resilience in the fisheries sector in Saint Lucia.” A first session was held with the group to determine the base line score. 36 persons were trained (16 men and 20 women) were trained in Leadership, cooperatives and climate change. 2) “Building consensus for the establishment of the St. Jacques agro-tourism landscape.” This project has met all its outputs as follows: (i) A rapid assessment of the watershed was completed along with a vulnerability assessment; (ii) Existing land use was mapped; (iii) the western boundary for the park was determined; and (iv) a planning framework was proposed. 3) “Sustainable employment for youth using indigenous fruits in and outside of the Qualibou Caldera.” A new value chain was established to enable farmers to sell fruits, which should encourage them to keep fruit trees planted, instead of cutting them to plant dasheen (a basic food commodity of the island) and such other crops that increases erosion. The women entrepreneurs won the 2018 Youth in Entrepreneurship for Saint Lucia.
In St. Vincent and Grenadines, the project “Sandy Bay eco-tourism, cultural and development project” has been implemented with a total of IWEco funding of $86,000. The project seeks to restore and preserve the environment while creating viable economic activity in the community by drawing on the history and culture of the people’s indigenous heritage.
In Trinidad and Tobago, two projects have been developed and implemented with a total of $87,000 IWEco fund. 1) “Building Climate Resilience through Community Led Rehabilitation.” More than one hectare of land has been rehabilitated. 5000 seedlings are produced and planted. 2) “Abandoned Quarry-Site Rehabilitation Project at National Quarries.” 13,000 vetiver plants installed in the environment. 2,000 vetiver plants set in nursery. In terms of international knowledge exchange under Component 4, IWEco supported:
 Participation of two (2) Cubans to the 21st World Congress of Soil Science (WCSS) 12 – 17 August 2018 in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil - Cuba
Meeting participation supported by IWEco included:
 The Caribbean Public Health Agency (CARPHA), in partnership with The Nature Conservancy (TNC) organized a regional training in Ecosystem Services Assessment and Valuation (ESAV) and Carbon Sequestration from 20 – 22 May 2019 as per Component 2 of the IWEco project. The purpose of the course was to supplement the investments from national projects in reforestation efforts and develop capacity to measure the contributions of the IWEco investments to climate change mitigation and adaptation. IWEco’s focus is currently on terrestrial activities while TNC is concentrating on marine issues. CARPHA, through IWEco funds, facilitated the participation of several professionals from IWEco project countries.
IW:LEARN Twinning: In November 2018, the IWEco project team attended the 9th IW Conference in Marrakesh, Morocco where the project won an award in the poster competition for “Best Poster”.
Also, as preparation for the baseline concerning marine litter policies in place in the Region, a consultant assisted with the formulation of a Marine Litter Policy Assessment Report (focusing on Styrofoam and Single Use plastic bags bans already in place/under preparation in the wider Caribbean region. The final report was presented at the 4th LBS COP on 4 June 2019.
It is expected that lead institutions OECS/CARPHA (with partners) under component 2 & 3 of the IWEco Project will further advance the policy and legislative aspects related to marine litter in the wider Caribbean Region. Work to develop and implement the IWEco Project website began in January 2019 with the hiring of a website consultant. Following consultation with the PCU and partners on needs, the website was designed and populated in time for introduction at the Third Regional Project Steering Committee Meeting in early April 2019. The RPSC3 approved the website as designed, following which it was finalized and launched on 30 April 2019. Training in maintenance of the website by the Communication Specialist, supported by members of the PCU, took place in May 2019. The website includes country specific pages and a dashboard to enable tracking of activities, an extensive photo gallery and links to IWEco’s social media accounts (Facebook, Instagram and Twitter).

• 75% change on revenue generation for most directly engaged stakeholders in agriculture, forestry, near-shore fisheries and other livelihoods • 80% change in revenue for most directly engaged stakeholders in eco-tourism o IWC7 Conference successfully hosted o At least 5 professionals and targeted stakeholders participated at IWC8

Progress of SGP Component
The implementation of the SGP component has been going well and as planned in most of the eight recipient countries, although they vary in their progress towards the implementation due to different contexts. Efforts to estimate the impact of COVID-19 are underway and an overview will be published ahead of the IWEco Project Steering Committee. In all countries, community projects have been developed and implemented with awareness raising, trainings or outreach activities. Meetings and workshops have been organized at the national level to enhance local capacity and awareness. Barbados, despite not receiving funds for national activities, has supported projects in alignment with the IWEco priorities. There is now a total of thirty (30) community demonstration sites in support of IWEco implementation.
In terms of expenditures, as of April 30, 2020, Outcome 2: SGP Component implemented approximately 70% of its allocated budget (Available budget: USD 973,000.00 / Implemented: USD 678,800.23). In addition, a commitment of grant projects of USD 180,707.72 is registered as of 29 of May 2020. This makes a reference to grant projects that were already earmarked by countries and represents the amount pending disbursements. Thus, the following countries are to finalize their grant projects as they reach their milestones and have the respective amounts to be disbursed: Cuba – USD 54,996.84; Saint Lucia- USD 49,527.00, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines – USD 42,622.00; Jamaica – USD 4,300.00; Dominican Republic – USD 8,700.00, Antigua and Barbuda – USD 15,000.00 and Saint Kitts and Nevis – USD 2,640.00
In Cuba, there are four (4) IWEco projects that are currently in progress: The IWEco funded projects that were already under implementation: (i) Reduction of contaminants from swine farming in areas of the San Juan watershed, Santiago de Cuba province and (ii) Conservation and sustainable management of natural resources for the benefit of the community in Rincon de Guanabo are 90% completed.
Two additional, SGP CORE-funded projects have been established in 2020, including: (iii) The fish conservation programme in the marine community of El Perché in Cienfuegos, which is expected to be finalized by October 2021. The project will develop: a. Three sustainable economic alternatives that relate to tourism (fishing without death, contemplation of marine biodiversity, and cultural traditions and crafts). b. New jobs for fishermens families, with affirmative actions of gender equity. c. A community monitoring system for the ecosystem of the bay and adjacent areas. (iv) The project for reduction of the degradation of the soils of the “El Mango” community, which is expected to be finalized by December 2020. The project has been approved by the National Steering Committee in May 2019 but is pending activation and approval according to national standards. In order to maintain the momentum of the initiative, training workshops have been held on raising dairy goats, the use of bio-fertilizers and bio-pesticides, and the use of live and dead barriers, etc. The project will develop: a. More than ten sustainable economic alternatives related to Sustainable Land Management (MST in Spanish) for adaptation to climate change and to reduce soil erosion and contamination of the waters of the Arimao river and the bay of Cienfuegos. b. New jobs for the community, with affirmative actions of gender equity. c. A community monitoring system for the agricultural ecosystem and their influence on the Arimao river and the bay of Cienfuegos.
In Antigua and Barbuda, there are four (4) projects under IWEco: the existing IWEco funded projects are still in progress (i) Creating value from coconut waste, (ii) Innovation in the use of microalgae cultivation, using sequestered CO2 from exhaust gases and nutrients from wastewater treatment, (iii) Metal recycling for ecosystem protection and community empowerment. On November 11, 2019, the SGP CORE funded project “Antigua Beekeepers Co-operative Society” was approved. A new National Coordinator is expected to start in August 2020.
In Dominican Republic, three IWEco-funded projects are still under implementation, the project (i) “Beekeeping in the communities of the Yerba Buena and Mata Palacio Municipalities” is expected to be finalized by November 2020, (ii) Rehabilitation of the Higuamo River is still in progress and (iii) Development of sustainable apiculture in Gonzalo, Los Limones and Mango Fresco, Cuenca del Río Higuamo is expected to be finalized by July 2020.
In Saint Lucia, there are three IWEco-funded projects (i) “Connecting cooperatives to the SDGs and commencing the formative stages of building climate change resilience in the fisheries sector in Saint Lucia”, which was stopped because the grantee partner organization ceased activity. The project did complete the outcome of training 36 fishers on cooperative principles and the SDGs. The project (ii) “Building consensus for the establishment of the St. Jacques agro-tourism landscape fond” completed the planning grant and now moved forward with the implementation of the full grant and the establishment of the Agro-tourism park. The grantee partner has been given a full grant to undertake foundational work as follows: (i) hiring two consultants to determine the financial and cost benefit of the proposed management area or park; and to develop the standards for various components of the project. Other components of the project include capacity development of locals and building the policy and political support for the establishment of this new management area in Saint Lucia. A third project was also completed (iii) “Sustainable employment for youth using indigenous fruits in and outside of the Qualibou Caldera” with IWEco funding. This project has been very successful and created full time employment for three ladies by establishing a small-scale Smoothie Enterprise, that serves as a market for small farmers.
In Jamaica, there are four (4) projects under implementation: two IWEco-funded projects that were already under implementation are set for closure in July (Biodiversity restoration through community engagement in the Portland Blight Protected Area) and September 2020 (Evaluating coastal water quality at Discovery Bay to improve capacity for environmental management). In addition, SGP CORE funded projects are in progress including the third project “Persons with disabilities protecting the marine ecosystems in the Negril Environmental Protection Area While Generating Sustainable Livelihoods” which is foreseen to be completed by August 2021.
The fourth project “Conserving the Natural Resources through Innovative Agricultural Techniques in the Negril Environmental Protection Area” just received co-financing and will start June 2020. This project will: a. Establish a Climate Smart Agriculture demonstration site, b. Increase awareness on sustainable land management in the Negril EPA, c. Improve livelihoods for the farming community.
In Saint Kitts and Nevis, six (6) projects are in progress or have recently been completed: the IWEco-funded projects are four; (i) Preserving the natural environment and contributing to the Island of Nevis’ Reforestation Programme is set to be closed by June 2020, (ii) the Water harvesting and storage to supply organic farm system project has been completed. The projects (iii) Youth involvement to promote the sustainable use of water, land and ecosystem resources in St. Kitts and Nevis and (iv) St. Peter’s water harvesting and storage community project, were scheduled for completion by March 2020. (Expected impact COVID-19 to be reported soon). In addition, the first of the SGP CORE funded projects “Combating land degradation on the historic New River and Coconut Walk coastline” was completed while a second one (Island-wide reforestation programme) is underway.
In Trinidad and Tobago, the two (2) IWEco-funded projects are completed; (i) Abandoned quarry-site rehabilitation at national quarries, (ii) Building climate resilience through community-led rehabilitation. The final reports will be available soon.
In Saint Vincent and Grenadines, there is one (1) IWEco-funded project of $150.000 USD (strategic grant) under implementation, the (i) Sandy Bay eco-tourism, cultural and development project. Call for proposals for matching SGP CORE funded projects are underway but delayed due to Covid-19. In Barbados, three SGP CORE funded projects that align with IWEco are in progress (i) Engaging the community and building capacity for coral reef restoration, (ii) Protected areas conservation and management programme for young citizen scientists or completed (iii) Participatory management for the Barbados Marine Management Area. • Participation of IWEco’s Technical Specialist in the GEF-Pacific R2R Project’s 4th Steering Committee meeting and related events in Nadi, Fiji, 29 July - 2 August 2019. This was an IW:LEARN supported exchange. A summary of the IWEco Project was presented, including the status of each participating country and an introduction to the Monitoring Dashboard. • Participation of IWEco’s Communication Specialist in the 13th Congress of the Caribbean Youth environment Network (CYEN), 12 – 13 August 2019, in Georgetown Guyana. The IWEco Project was introduced and possible areas of collaboration were discussed. The Cartagena Convention Secretariat’s work in the area of Marine Litter was also shared and discussions held for five CYEN country chapters participation in International Coastal Clean-up activities supported by GCFI, as well, as significantly, producing public awareness products and collecting local data. • IWEco’s participation in the Caribbean Water and Wastewater Association’s 28th Annual Conference and Exhibition, 14 – 17 October 2019, in Saint Kitts & Nevis, included an Exhibit shared with the Cartagena Convention. It featured project interventions in St. Kitts & Nevis, Saint Lucia and Trinidad and Tobago as well as the work of an NGO from Saint Maarten, Waste2Work, which upcycles hurricane debris and waste to encourage sustainable waste management. IWEco also held a Technical Session, featuring a series of Project presentations, on 16th October which was very well attended.

The UNDP/SGP Component has been very successful in terms of stakeholder engagement despite some challenges in different countries. Through SGP’s multi-stakeholder National Steering Committee and its long-established networks, SGP was able to engage the government, civil society organizations, academia, and other key stakeholders. For instance, in Trinidad and Tobago, following a series of discussions with key stakeholders, a wide range of actors were brought on board and contributed significantly to the success of the “Abandoned Quarry Site Rehabilitation Project at National Quarries, Turure Road, Sangre Grande” project. Among the most important: SusTrust, IAMovement, NQCL, Carib Glass, among others. In Antigua and Barbuda, stakeholder engagement was very impressive in the “Educational and Empowerment pathways for metal recycling in Antigua and Barbuda” project. The first phase of the project involved an extensive consultation with a wide range of stakeholders including the Fire Department, National Solid Waste Management Authority, Antigua Public Utilities Authority (APUA), Department of Analytical Services, Environmental Awareness Group (EAG), Waste Pickers, Marine Ecosystem Protected Areas Trust (MEPA), Department of the Environment, Zero Waste Antigua Barbuda (ZWAB), Integrated Health Outreach (IHO), Ministry of Tourism and Investment and Antigua Barbuda Waste Recycling Corporation. Following this, all stakeholders provided their support in various ways to ensure the success of the project. In another project “Biodiversity Restoration in the Portland Bight Protected Area through community engagement” in Jamaica, a high degree of stakeholder engagement led to project success and key stakeholders including the Caribbean Coastal Area Management Foundation, National Environment and Planning Agency (NEPA), Jamaica Fire Brigade (JFB), Clarendon Municipal Corporation (CMC) and the Forestry Department (FD) have signed an MOU to continue to support the project. This MOU will last for three years and will focus on fire management and continuous training of community members in the Portland Ridge area. The UNDP/SGP Component ensured that all consultations involved both male and female from youth to senior citizens, and that the decision to involve people in discussions and project activities was not based on their gender. Participants, both male and female were given the same access to training, information sharing, and any other support needed to carry out project activities. In close collaboration with UNDP which implements the SGP projects in the project countries, between May and June 2021, 4 short case studies were prepared for eventual inclusion in a compendium of SGP in IWEco experience. Ten Case studies are planned in total, including topics like “Abandoned Quarry Site Rehabilitation Project at National Quarries, Turure Road, Sangre Grande, Trinidad & Tobago”, “Educational and Empowerment pathways for metal recycling in Antigua and Barbuda”, “Evaluating Discovery Bay Inshore Coastal Water Quality to improve Capacity for environmental Management, Jamaica”, “Harvesting and Storing Water to Adequately Supply an Open Organic Farm System, St. Kitts and Nevis”, and “Beekeeping in communities of the municipalities of Yerba Buena and Mata Palacio, Dominican Republic”.
